description:
changed the default length for binary Gadget files to comoving kpc/h to match Gadget-2 users guide

made it so that OWLS/Eagle units are read directly from file

Added Eagle (cosmological non-zoom) I/O

Updated _is_valid routines to be able to differentiate between OWLS and Eagle snapshots.
title: update to Gadget/OWLS/Eagle frontends

content.raw:
Can you elaborate a bit regarding the difference between `EagleDataset` and `EagleNetworkDataset`?  Why doesn't this subclass `OWLSDataset`?

Do we have test datasets for each of these `Dataset` subclasses on yt-project.org/data?
content.html:
Can you elaborate a bit regarding the difference between EagleDataset and EagleNetworkDataset? Why doesn't this subclass OWLSDataset?

Do we have test datasets for each of these Dataset subclasses on yt-project.org/data?

content.raw:
`EagleDataset` is the base regular output from the Eagle project.  These are all cosmological non-zoom runs.  `EagleNetworkDataset` are the zoom-in runs done subsequently that focus on higher resolution galaxy simulations and include a large chemical network called the EagleNetwork.  I think its confusing to subclass the OWLSDataset b/c Eagle is a different project and while OWLS and Eagle, and EagleNetwork outputs are hdf5 gadget data sets, it is not true that Eage outputs are a specific type of OWLS output.  

We have test datasets for OWLSDataset and EagleDataset, but not the EagleNetworkDataset.  I think we need permission from Ben Openheimer and collaborators.  Hillary will know about the progress on this front.
content.html:
EagleDataset is the base regular output from the Eagle project. These are all cosmological non-zoom runs. EagleNetworkDataset are the zoom-in runs done subsequently that focus on higher resolution galaxy simulations and include a large chemical network called the EagleNetwork. I think its confusing to subclass the OWLSDataset b/c Eagle is a different project and while OWLS and Eagle, and EagleNetwork outputs are hdf5 gadget data sets, it is not true that Eage outputs are a specific type of OWLS output.

We have test datasets for OWLSDataset and EagleDataset, but not the EagleNetworkDataset. I think we need permission from Ben Openheimer and collaborators. Hillary will know about the progress on this front.

content.raw: Then shouldn't `EagleNetworkDataset` subclass this?
content.html: Then shouldn't EagleNetworkDataset subclass this?

content.raw: We're using subclasses here to avoid code duplication.  I'm worried about all the copy/paste here, since it makes it very easy to fix a bug in one place and then not fix it in the others.
content.html: We're using subclasses here to avoid code duplication. I'm worried about all the copy/paste here, since it makes it very easy to fix a bug in one place and then not fix it in the others.

content.raw: yes, I think that makes more sense.  although I didn't want to mess with Hillarys updates until we have something to test the routines on in the public space.
content.html: yes, I think that makes more sense. although I didn't want to mess with Hillarys updates until we have something to test the routines on in the public space.

content.raw:
This might break user scripts.  I think this was originally set to 1 comoving megaparsec for AGORA, which probably had that set in the parameter file.

I'd be less nervous about this if we had a way to read gadget parameter files and extract this information automagically.  It's unfortunate that this information isn't encoded in the binary file.
content.html:
This might break user scripts. I think this was originally set to 1 comoving megaparsec for AGORA, which probably had that set in the parameter file.

I'd be less nervous about this if we had a way to read gadget parameter files and extract this information automagically. It's unfortunate that this information isn't encoded in the binary file.

content.raw: I'll see what can be gathered into the GadgetHDF5Dataset class
content.html: I'll see what can be gathered into the GadgetHDF5Dataset class

content.raw: I can change it back.  It's no big deal, I was just going for consistency with the Users Guide, but if people are already using 1 Mpc/h for Agora it makes sense to leave it like that.
content.html: I can change it back. It's no big deal, I was just going for consistency with the Users Guide, but if people are already using 1 Mpc/h for Agora it makes sense to leave it like that.

content.raw: Nah, this is definitely the correct setting, I'm just nervous about breaking scripts that subtly depended on this behavior and wanted to raise the issue here.
content.html: Nah, this is definitely the correct setting, I'm just nervous about breaking scripts that subtly depended on this behavior and wanted to raise the issue here.

content.raw: these 4 lines can all be put intot the base GadgetDataset class right?
content.html: these 4 lines can all be put intot the base GadgetDataset class right?

content.raw: Any logic that's shared by all subclasses can be refactored into the base class.  So yes, so long as these four lines are correct in all circumstances.
content.html: Any logic that's shared by all subclasses can be refactored into the base class. So yes, so long as these four lines are correct in all circumstances.

content.raw: It occurs to me: shouldn't there be a check for whether or not the dataset is cosmological?  If not, this should be 1.0 kpc, not kpccm/h.
content.html: It occurs to me: shouldn't there be a check for whether or not the dataset is cosmological? If not, this should be 1.0 kpc, not kpccm/h.

content.raw: it's in there.  its just bundled with a check of self._unit_base.  I just don't know what self._unit_base is so didn't want to change the logic.  A few lines down also has branches for cosmo / no cosmo
content.html: it's in there. its just bundled with a check of self._unit_base. I just don't know what self._unit_base is so didn't want to change the logic. A few lines down also has branches for cosmo / no cosmo

content.raw: The branch that checks if the dataset is non-cosmological only gets entered if `UnitLength_in_cm` is in `_unit_base`, no?  `unit_base` is used by the sph frontend to pass in user-selected units.
content.html: The branch that checks if the dataset is non-cosmological only gets entered if UnitLength_in_cm is in _unit_base, no? unit_base is used by the sph frontend to pass in user-selected units.

content.raw: Good catch!
content.html: Good catch!

content.raw: Im confused why we find an analytic time here instead of reading in from the dataset, but Im not sure if thats because I dont understand gadget! In the Eagle dataset that is on the hub there is a hvals['Time'] field that when you read in and do the same conversion you do for OWLS on line 371, I get 3.155e+16 s. When I look at the current time with this analytic solution it shows 4.361e+17 s. Is one of those wrong?
content.html: Im confused why we find an analytic time here instead of reading in from the dataset, but Im not sure if thats because I dont understand gadget! In the Eagle dataset that is on the hub there is a hvals['Time'] field that when you read in and do the same conversion you do for OWLS on line 371, I get 3.155e+16 s. When I look at the current time with this analytic solution it shows 4.361e+17 s. Is one of those wrong?

content.raw: Im not sure how necessary this is, but following convention you might want to add EagleDataset to yt.frontends.sph.api
content.html: Im not sure how necessary this is, but following convention you might want to add EagleDataset to yt.frontends.sph.api

content.raw: Thanks for taking a look Hilary.  There is indeed a header value called `Time` in the `Eagle` snapshots, but it is the scale factor, not the time in Gyr.  So when you multiply the z=0, a=1 `Time` in the Eagle snapshot by the number of seconds in a Gyr, you get the number of seconds in a Gyr or 3.155e16.  I don't know why they didn't include `Time_GYR` in the Eagle snapshots.  Looks to me like an oversight when merging OWLS and newer versions of Gadget.
content.html: Thanks for taking a look Hilary. There is indeed a header value called Time in the Eagle snapshots, but it is the scale factor, not the time in Gyr. So when you multiply the z=0, a=1 Time in the Eagle snapshot by the number of seconds in a Gyr, you get the number of seconds in a Gyr or 3.155e16. I don't know why they didn't include Time_GYR in the Eagle snapshots. Looks to me like an oversight when merging OWLS and newer versions of Gadget.

content.raw: Ohhh got it! That definitely seems like an oversight, you're right. Then my only other comment would be that EagleNetworkDataset should probably superclass EagleDataset instead of OWLSDataset. I checked that it loads fine if you do that, and it still references `Time` at the moment.
content.html: Ohhh got it! That definitely seems like an oversight, you're right. Then my only other comment would be that EagleNetworkDataset should probably superclass EagleDataset instead of OWLSDataset. I checked that it loads fine if you do that, and it still references Time at the moment.

content.raw: Good suggestion, totally forgot about that!
content.html: Good suggestion, totally forgot about that!

content.raw: cool, I'll add that update to this pull request.
content.html: cool, I'll add that update to this pull request.

content.raw: So this looks good, and I think it underscores that we can figure out simpler ways of differentiating different "classes" of simulations through field detection and the like.  But, right now, this is the best solution.  Thanks, @galtay .
